Alopecia Areata.Recommendation: Consult a dermatologist immediately. Early intervention can help manage symptoms.
Alopecia Areata.Why: Autoimmune condition where the immune system attacks hair follicles.

Contact Dermatitis.Recommendation: Visit a dermatologist to identify and avoid triggers. Medical creams may be prescribed.
Contact Dermatitis.Why: Caused by allergic reactions or irritants leading to scalp inflammation.

Folliculitis.Recommendation: Seek medical advice. A doctor may prescribe antibiotics or antifungal treatment.
Folliculitis.Why: Infection of hair follicles leading to bumps, itching, or pain.

Head Lice.Recommendation: See a doctor or pharmacist for proper medicated shampoos and treatment guidance.
Head Lice.Why: Parasitic infestation that causes intense itching and scalp irritation.

Lichen Planus.Recommendation: Consult a dermatologist for anti-inflammatory or immunosuppressive treatment.
Lichen Planus.Why: Chronic inflammatory condition that can cause scalp scarring and hair loss.

Male Pattern Baldness.Recommendation: Seek medical advice. Treatments like minoxidil or finasteride may help slow progression.
Male Pattern Baldness.Why: Genetic hair loss condition common in men, often progressive.

Psoriasis.Recommendation: Visit a dermatologist for medicated shampoos and treatments to reduce scalp plaques.
Psoriasis.Why: Chronic autoimmune condition causing flaky, itchy scalp.

Seborrheic Dermatitis.Recommendation: Consult a dermatologist. Antifungal shampoos or topical treatments may be required.
Seborrheic Dermatitis.Why: Causes dandruff and inflamed, greasy scalp.

Telogen Effluvium.Recommendation: See a doctor to identify stressors or underlying conditions causing temporary shedding.
Telogen Effluvium.Why: Often triggered by stress, illness, or hormonal changes.

Tinea Capitis.Recommendation: Consult a doctor for antifungal medications. Early treatment prevents spreading.
Tinea Capitis.Why: Fungal infection of the scalp leading to hair loss and scaly patches.
